RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 8th October 2018 - Stocks pare back some losses but tech lags behind; US Columbus Day
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries (futures) flat, crude down, dollar up.

* REAR-VIEW: EU letter states Italy’s budget “serious concern”, European Commission not to adopt draft Brexit text, Fed’s Bullard says at a good level of rates today, ECB’s Knot upbeat on EU economy, US Columbus Day.

* AHEAD:  German Trade Balance, Fed's Kaplan, Evans & Harker to speak, BoE's Carney & Broadbent to speak.

 

* ITALY:  An EU Commission letter stated the targets in Italy budget are a source of "serious concern”, with the report weighing on BTPs and European bourses on Monday. In response, Italian PM Conte’s office reportedly said Italy wants constructive dialogue with the EU whilst Deputy PM Salvini said they will not backtrack on their budget plans, despite market pressure. In later comments, Italy’s European Affairs Minister Savona stressed that no one in the government wants to leave the EU noting that if growth does not go as well as expected next year the government will hike public investments. Also, ECB's Villeroy commented on Italy stating “you could judge Italian debt as too risky, Italian mix of high debt and weak growth is unbalanced”.

* BREXIT: The RTE reported on Monday the European Commission will not formally adopt a draft text on UK relationship on Wednesday when EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier was scheduled to present the draft political declaration to EU commissioners and ambassadors. RTE Journalist Tony Connelly noted this could be because “things are being so sensitive ahead of next weeks’ EU summit that all sides go into a blackout to avoid leaks and eruptions”. A UK PM May Spokesman reported that the Northern Irish backstop proposal will be published in due course and there is no precise date, adding that the EU still needs to move its position in negotiations. As a reminder, on Tuesday the UK Cabinet meeting takes place (Brexit not formally listed on draft agenda).

* TRADE: An official reported the US Treasury is concerned about recent CNY depreciation and are monitoring developments; he has also said they are willing to talk to China on trade.

* FED: Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) said now at a good level of rates and he does not think rates will have to rise much more to contain inflation. He added now have entered lower end of neutral estimates for rates and must decide whether to go further; he believes the US needs quicker productivity growth to maintain GDP growth rates. On the December rate meeting, he noted data is looking good today but let's see when the meeting comes around. He also stressed the Fed is watching international developments and he is concerned they will feed back to the US economy. He noted both China and the US seem to be digging in and he would like to see both sides come to the table he adds that new North American trade agreement sends the message that trade wars can be settled. He also noted the dot plot model for forecasting interest rate expectations isn't perfect. Finally, he indicated the long term US rate rise provides room on the issue of the yield curve, which is a welcome development.

* ECB: ECB's Knot said overall inflation has been above our definition of price stability for several months; Euro area inflation outlook unaffected by Italy thus far. He added the ECB could say something about the possible number of interest rate hikes per year, like the Fed does. He sees no reason to feel uncomfortable with market expectations for 2-3 years app reinvestments.

* SPX -0.01% at 2885, NDX -0.62% at 7353, DJI +0.16% at 26488. SECTORS: Energy -0.05%, Materials 0.00%, Industrials +0.20%, Cons Discretionary +0.04%, Cons Staples +1.34%, Healthcare -0.17%, Financials +0.60%, Tech -1.18%, Telecoms -0.15%, Utilities +0.78%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Arconic (ARNC) lead the SPX after reports of several private equity firms in talks over a joint bid. General Electric (GE) caught a bid on the back of an upgrade at Barclays, echoing recent new CEO optimism. Conagra Brands (CAG) also benefitted on an upgrade at UBS. Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) was another top mover after a price target rise at RBC Capital. Mid-session saw the announcement that De Shaw is joining Continental Grain’s push for change at Bunge Limited (BG) giving the stock a push upward. Tech stocks took the biggest hit today with names like Salesforce.Com (CRM) and Workday (WDAY) down significantly. Morgan Stanley cut casino revenue estimates for the Macau region, stocks hit included Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and MGM Resorts (MGM). Apple (AAPL) was also down on the day, keeping indexes and the tech sector down.

* WTI (X8) SETTLES USD 0.05 LOWER AT USD 74.29/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.25 LOWER AT USD 83.91/BBL. Brent and WTI were both on the defensive on Monday, with traders continuing to cite last week's news that the US could potentially grant waivers to certain buyers of Iranian crude. "While no specifics on waivers have yet been discussed, anything that allows more Iranian crude to find its way into global markets will be perceived as negative for oil in the near term," UBS said, "markets are still tight and spare capacity is still limited, but it is understandable that oil prices have pulled back while we await additional details on how extensive sanctions waivers might be." Additionally, last week's talk of the Saudis and Russians being able to ramp production to offset export declines in Iran continues to be cited. At the margin, a stronger dollar on Monday did little to help the crude complex. In energy specific news, a fire was reported at the Irving's St John refinery in Canada (300k BPD) which lent some positive ticks.

US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) UNCHNAGED AT 117-23+. Treasury futures mirrored action seen in Bunds on Monday amid thin volume; the complex drifted higher as European traders got to their desks given concern expressed by the EU Commission on Italy’s budget plan whilst actions remained limited in US trade. Note due to public holiday the cash treasury market was closed for Columbus Day.

* DXY: The index and broad Usd have rebounded further from last Friday’s post-NFP lows, albeit not uniformly as the safer-havens are bucking the trend, but enough to nudge the DXY back up towards 96.000. Market holidays in Japan and the US ahead (latter only partial) may have exacerbated price action/moves, but it’s certainly been a risk-off return from Golden Week in China and the Italian budget issue continues weigh on investor sentiment. Back to the Dollar, or rather the index, and beyond the big figure last week’s peak was 96.124.

* CAD: Losing against the USD as oil prices retreat to compound the overall downturn in risk sentiment, and the Loonie retreating below 1.3000.

* EUR, GBP: The next major underperformers, and both losing grip of round numbers/psychological handles in relatively quick order amidst stops and the aforementioned bearish factors. The single currency is under 1.1500 and Cable sub-1.3100, but the former is holding above decent option expiry interest at 1.1450 (1.5 bn) and the latter has regained some poise having tested 1.3050 stops, with Brexit impulses still supportive on balance.

* JPY: A clean break of stops at 113.50, and chart supports at 113.56/113.42 (Tenkan and Fib respectively) has propelled the Jpy up to almost 113.25 at one point vs the Greenback as the more attractive currency of the pairing during periods of pronounced risk aversion.

* NZD, AUD, CHF: All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, as the Kiwi and Aud pair some losses off fresh lows circa 0.6425 and 0.7040 respectively, while the Franc remains capped ahead of 0.9900, albeit bouncing firmly through 1.1400 against the Eur. 

* EM: A bit of a mixed bag in terms of performance across the region, with the Rand hit hard after rumours/reports that SA Finance Minister may quit, but the Lira holding up better vs a strong Dollar ahead of the Government’s inflation combating measures due to be announced on Tuesday. Similarly, the Peso is benefiting from pre-positioning before the Real re-opens after Sunday’s Brazilian election and a bigger than anticipated 1st round victory by Bolsonaro. However, the Rouble has been undermined by a retreat in Brent and unable to reap the reward of speculation that US sanctions may be less harsh after mid-term elections. Usd/Zar around 14.8500, Usd/Try near 6.1600, Usd/Mxn close to 18.8300 and Usd/Rub hovering just under 67.0000.

UBS Weekly FX Flows report: SEK & USD bought while NOK & EUR sold amid higher US yields and Italy risk
content:
• USD saw inflows for the first time in three weeks despite mixed September payrolls data as the US 10-year yield reached its highest level since 2011.
  • SEK registered the largest G10 FX inflows on a normalized basis, experiencing strong buying interest at the end of the week despite a softer global risk backdrop.
  • CHF recorded inflows for the first time in five weeks, with buying more or less coinciding with spikes in BTP spreads as Italian headline risks  linger.
  • GBP was net bought, with the heaviest daily inflows coinciding with reports on Friday that a Brexit deal was said to be 'very close' by EU negotiators.
  • NOK was the most sold G10 currency for a second week in a row despite higher oil prices and a relatively light data week.
  • EUR was sold for the first time in three weeks amid a spike in US yields and market uncertainty around the Italian budget.
  • NZD registered strong selling while AUD was sold for the first time in four weeks.

Daily FX Wrap: Gbp hits Brexit buffers, Eur on Italian rocks, but Usd and Jpy on safe ground
content:
EUR/GBP

Extending earlier losses and now at the bottom of the G10 pile, as the single currency stumbles on latest EU worries over Italy’s budget and defiance from Rome, while in contrast more positive overtures from the EU on Brexit amidst reports of anywhere checks for exports to Ireland do not seem to be welcomed by the UK that still has reservations on outstanding borders issues. Eur/Usd retreated further from 1.1500+ levels to breach the prior October low (1.1464) and September’s base, but just held above hefty option expiries at the 1.1450 strike (1.5 bn), while Cable took out stops around 1.3050 before finding some underlying bids ahead of daily chart support at 1.3013 around 1.3030.

CAD

The Loonie found some traction alongside crude to bounce from 1.3010 lows vs its US peer, but remained weak overall and still well off last Friday’s post-Canadian employment report peaks.

JPY

The major outperformer due to broad risk aversion that started overnight in Asia with the return of Chinese markets from Golden Week and sharp slides in stocks, the Yuan and contagion (Nikkei aside given Japan’s holiday). Usd/Jpy saw stops triggered on a break of 113.50 after failing to hold above 113.56 (Tankan level) and then breached 113.42 (Fib) on the way to almost 113.00, while Eur/Jpy took out 130.00, eventually.

AUD/NZD

The antipodean Dollars both survived further pressure amidst the ongoing US-China/global trade stand-off to rebound off new lows for the recent slide circa 0.7040 and 0.6425 vs their US counterpart, as the CNH also pared some losses on reports that the US Treasury is worried about Yuan weakness and is keeping an eye on developments. Note, the PBoC sent the Usd/Cny midpoint at 6.8957 overnight vs 6.8792 ahead of Golden Week and Usd/Cnh rallied to 6.9370 at one stage.

CHF

Ending Monday’s EU session relatively flat vs the Usd and within a fairly tight 0.9910-45 range with little independent impetus for the Franc.

EM

The Brl was buoyed by the stronger than predicted showing from Bolsonaro at the weekend Brazilian election that puts him in poll position for the second round on October 28th, albeit not certain to prevail vs his main rival. However, the Real rallied more than 3% at best towards 3.7100 vs the Usd in marked contrast to the Rand that encountered bearish domestic political impulses via press speculation about the potential resignation of SA Finance Minister Nene (subsequently played down by President Ramaphosa’s office, but not categorically denied). Usd/Zar off highs just over 14.9800, but still some 0.5% ahead on the day. Elsewhere, Usd/Try also on the retreat, from circa 6.1900 to fresh lows form the day near 6.1140 and eagerly awaiting inflation-fighting measures from the Government due tomorrow.

Indeed, BTPs remain some 1.5 full points adrift and precarious vs firm Bunds and to a lesser extent Gilts, while the Jpy and Usd are still outperforming in the currency space with very few exceptions, like the Brl on political grounds.   • Baker Hughes (BHGE) – The oil co. has formed a strategic partnership with Abu Dhabi National Oil Co. to enable and support its subsidiary drilling co. to grow and develop into a fully-integrated drilling and well construction provider, the transaction values the drilling co. at USD 11bln. (Newswires)
  • Ensco (ESV) – The co. agreed to buy its smaller rival Rowan Cos in an all-stock deal valued at USD 2.38bln to expand its rig fleet. Ensco shareholders will own 60.5% of the combined entity. (Newswires)
  • Ford (F) – The automaker is said to be making cuts to its salaried workforce in attempts to make the co. more efficient. (Newswires)
  • Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) – The copper producer’s CEO, Richard Adkerson, says that the co. plans to remain independent, but all strategic options remain on the table, including a sale. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – Apollo (APO) is to acquire USD 1bln equity portfolio from the GE Capital unit. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM) – The automaker’s quarterly sales in China at the end of September were down 14.9% for the first time in more than a year due to a slowdown in the auto market amid trade tensions with the US as well economic growth uncertainty. (Newswires)
  • MGM Resorts (MGM) - Morgan Stanley cuts price target to USD 32 from USD 34. (Newswires)  
  • Moody’s (MCO) – The bank Santander UK (SAN SM) has chosen Moody’s Analytics modelling technology for its operations. (Newswires)
  • Northern Trust (NTRS) – The asset manager has hired Wouter Sturkenboom, previously at Russell Investments, as its chief investment strategist for the EMEA region. (Newswires)
  • Quest Diagnostics (DGX) – The healthcare co. is to sell its India medical diagnostics business to Bangalore-based diagnostics co., Strand Life Sciences; expected to close Q1 2019. (Newswires)
  • Royal Caribbean Cruises (RCL) – The cruises co. announced an agreement to build three new ships for Silversea Cruises, an ultra-luxury and expedition cruise brand; agreements are subject to contingencies and expected to be completed in Q1 2019 and for delivery in March 2020. (Newswires)
  • Starbucks (SBUX) – The coffee maker names Patrick Grismer as CFO, succeeding Scott Maw who will retire on November 30th. (Newswires)
  • Target (TGT) – The retailer has announced the launch of the low-cost household goods brand, Smartly, in its stores. Prices will range from USD 0.59 to USD 11.99 with the majority under USD 2.00. (Newswires)
  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – Morgan Stanley cuts price target to USD 139 from USD 187. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s said Western Union (WU) was somewhere between MoneyGram International (MGI) and PayPal (PYPL), saying it still has a long way to go before it is a match for PayPal. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s writes that the duopoly card providers Visa (V), Mastercard (MA), who usually simultaneously move in similar directions, have diverged recently where Mastercard has moved ahead of Visa. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s positive on Asset Managers this week, where it says large names such as Fidelity, Vanguard, Capital Group, BlackRock (BLK), Charles Schwab (SCHW), State Street (STT), and T. Rowe Price Group (TROW) are set to grow larger and more specialised/boutique names are set to become increasingly niche. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s writes Amazon’s (AMZN) wage boost is seen as a sign of things to come across the country as other employees will face pressure to rise wages. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s writes this week that California’s new law, that will require public co.s in the state with five or more directors to have at least two or three female board members, will be a good test for Tesla (TSLA) to show its balance of diversity, independence and financial performance. Barron’s also writes that Tesla is proof that CEOs should not use Twitter (TWTR). (Newswires)
  • Barron’s says US Cloud Players (MSFT, GOOGL, FB, AMZN) are ramping up their capital expenditure on data centres, where they will account for 60% of their combined outlays this year. This is creating a tail-wind for other cheaper cloud focused names such as Eaton (ETN) and Terex (TEX). (Newswires)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – The tech giant has reached a cash settlement with job applicants who claim they were discriminated against over their ages; terms not yet disclosed. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The online retail giant has fired an employee after the individual shared customer details to third-party sellers. (Newswires)
  • Biogen (BIIB) – The biotech co. has announced new interim results from its efficacy and safety study, NURTURE, of Spinraza in 25 infants with SMA. As of May, all patients were still alive and 22 were able to walk either with assistance or independently. (Newswires)
  • Comcast (CMCSA) – UK culture minister Jeremy Wright has warned the broadcaster he will do whatever is necessary to ensure that its recently acquired UK based Sky (SKY LN) maintains its editorial independence. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co.’s messenger service is reportedly testing voice commands to dictate and send messages, initiate voice calls and create reminders. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Amdocs (DOX), Fortinet (FTNT) – Software co. Amdocs has partnered with Fortinet and Versa Networks for the launch of a new multi-domain, service provider SD-WAN, SDN and NFV orchestration packaged solution. (Newswires)
  • Axalta Coating (AXTA) – The co. reaffirms Q3 Adj. EBITDA guidance. CEO Hahn has resigned following an investigation by an outside counsel by him unrelated to financial matters and Robert Bryant is to replace him. (Newswires)
  • Blackstone (BX) – The investment co. has launched a renewable power focused investment co. that will invest in assets in the Middle East and Africa. (Newswires)
  • Brazilian-listed Bombardier (BBD), Petroleo Brasil (PBR), Itau Unibanco Holding (ITUB), Centrais Eletri (EBR), iShares (EWZ) – The Brazil-based names are up pre-market after far-right candidate Bolsonaro won the first round of elections but failed to get an outright victory, as he managed to bag 46.1% of valid votes (short of the 50% needed for an outright victory) while left-wing Workers’ Party candidate Haddad came second with 29.2%. (Newswires)
  • Celanese (CE) – The chemicals co. is raising its prices on Acetic Acid by USD 60/MT and on Vinyl Acetate Monomer, Acetic Anhydride, Butyl Acetate, and Ethyl Acetate by USD 50/MT. (Newswires)
  • KKR (KKR) – The private equity firm has launched a conditional USD 1.24bln takeover bid for the Australian accounting software co. MYOB Group, this is after purchasing a 19.9% stake. (Newswires)
  • Square (SQ) – The software co. has had its price target raised to USD 108 from USD 77 at Goldman Sachs. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

subject: The European Commission will not formally adopt a draft text on UK relationship on Wednesday; according to RTE
content:
This comes from RTE Journalist Tony Connelly, with a thread highlighted below that can be found here

  • Here's a brief thread on where we're at with Brexit: My understanding is that @MichelBarnier will NOT produce a draft on the Political Declaration on Wed as had been expected. At the very most it'll be an annotated paper (headings, no text) and even then it won't be adopted Wed
  • This is all due to the "tunnel" factor, ie things being so sensitive ahead of next weeks EU summit that all sides go into a blackout to avoid leaks + eruptions. The next step is the UK's backstop proposals but even that will be teased out in talks rather than formal publication
  • Both the EU + UK may decide to try and nail down the Withdrawal Agreement first, then focus on the Political Declaration between the Oct + Nov summits, but that has an obvious disadvantage for the UK...
  • London would like to use the PD for leverage: ie, we won't agree to the backstop, unless we like what's in the Political Declaration. It also means that the WA, including the backstop, wd have to survive intense scrutiny in the UK in the weeks between the two summits...
  • Either way, both big elements will be hard to "digest" if the EU + UK try to get both over the line ahead of next Wed/Thurs, hence no major publications this week. Instead it wll all be about "tunnel" discussions (Olly Robbins is though to be in Brussels for same).
  • Much hinges on the UK backstop proposals and what they mean by a UK-wide customs backstop. Member states want to be helpful, but need detail. April 29 Negotiating Guidelines refer to "unique circumstances" on island of Ireland, so that's already a marker against UK-wide
  • The French are said to have an "open mind" but won't agree to any proposal that undermines the integrity of the single market and the EU's autonomy on decision making. Either way, "tentative" is the watch word on all fronts
analysis_details:
Note on Wednesday 10th, EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier was to present the draft political declaration to EU commissioners and ambassadors.

In addition this week:

  • 8th UK Brexit Secretary Raab to meet with EU Chief Negotiator Barnier
  • 9th UK Cabinet meeting (Brexit not formally listed on draft agenda)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • EUR, EU equities and BTPs hit as Italian budget targets seen as a “serious concern” for the European Commission
  • China returns with a RRR cut, but can’t stop the rot for Chinese equities and the CNH
  • Looking ahead the highlight is ECB’s Nowotny; NOTE: US Columbus Day is today, US equity markets are open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded on the backfoot as the region mimicked the lead from Wall St. where the S&P 500 posted its worst week in nearly a month as the tech sector underperformed, while Nasdaq Comp. pulled back over a percent as tech giants lagged and the Dow notched its second straight weekly declines as the index was pressured by heavyweights Intel and Caterpillar. ASX 200 (-1.3%) was weighed on by material and financial names following ANZ’s profit warning which dragged the likes of CBA, WBC and NAB lower in sympathy, while KOSPI (-0.6%) initially outperformed amid positive developments in the Korean peninsula before dipping in the red and Nikkei 225 is closed due to a public holiday in Japan.  Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-3.7%) plummeted as mainland China played catch-up, with participants re-entering the market and reacting to last week’s trade developments, rising yields, China downgrades and weak Caixin manufacturing data. Hang Seng (-1.3%) eroded initial gains as sentiment turned sour along with the mainland.

PBoC cut the RRR for some banks by 100bps to 14.50% from 15.50% (effective Oct 15th) in order to release CNY 750bln of liquidity. This is the fourth cut this year, while the central bank said it will continue to adopt prudent, neutral monetary policy and added the cut will not lead to pressure of CNY depreciation. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8957 (Prev. 6.8792) (weakest since May 11th 2017)
PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 100bln.

US Commerce Secretary Ross said he does not expect movement on China talks until after midterms, he added the USMCA 'non-market country' clause to act as a poison pill against potential trade deals with China, and the US could be replicated in future trade deals with EU and Japan. (Newswires)

US Department of Homeland Security said they have no reason to question denials by US tech firms that Chinese spies infiltrated US computer networks via microchips. (Newswires)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI Sep 53.1 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.5) (Newswires)
China Caixin Composite PMI (Sep) 52.1 (Prev. 52.0)

EU/UK/US

Head of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker told Austrian press that the chance of the UK and the EU agreeing a Brexit deal has grown in the last few days. He added that while he was not sure an agreement could be reached by October, it could be by November. Juncker declined to comment on whether he believed that Brexit might yet be avoided, given the divisions in the British government and parliament on the issue. (BBC/ The Guardian)

The EU is preparing to offer Theresa May a “supercharged” free trade deal this week but will reject Mrs May’s demands for frictionless trade, it has emerged. The offer from Brussels, which will be put to British negotiators on Wednesday, is said to contain “30 to 40 per cent” of the demands made in Mrs May’s Chequers proposal. (The Telegraph/Times) The Telegraph also reports that UK PM May will soon have to tell the UK that the country will be forced to stay in the Customs Union. (The Telegraph)

The Telegraph reported that Brexiteers offered UK PM May a lifeline that will see EU officials based at UK borders in a package of concessions to help unlock a Canada-style trade deal with Brussels. (The Telegraph) Reports in the Independent took a slightly different spin on the situation by stating that Conservative Brexiteers are giving UK PM May an ultimatum, that if her negotiating strategy fails she must accept plans for a Canada-style trade deal or face a leadership challenge. (The Independent) Further to this, the Times reports that Brexiteers have issued a last-ditch threat to vote down the budget and destroy the government unless UK PM May takes a tougher line with Brussels. The Times also reported that Brexiteers warned UK PM May that she could keep the UK within the EU customs arrangements only until 2022. (The Times)

UK PM May has appealed to Labour voters unhappy with Labour leader Corbyn's leadership to consider switching to the Conservatives. Writing in the Observer the PM insisted her party had a "moderate and patriotic programme". (BBC) May has also drawn up plans for a secret charm offensive aimed at persuading dozens of Labour MPs to back her Brexit deal even if it costs Labour leader Corbyn the chance to be PM, the Guardian has learned. Senior Tories say they have been in private contact with a number of Labour MPs over several months. (The Guardian) The Telegraph reported that UK Government whips in talks with 25 Labour MPs to push Chequers deal through Parliament. (The Telegraph)

SNP leader Sturgeon has said her MPs would back a new Brexit referendum if there is a vote to approve one in parliament. (The Independent)

Japanese PM Abe said he would welcome the UK to a TPP trade deal with "open arms". (FT)

The ECB warns banks to curtail booking trades and loans in UK post-Brexit; three people familiar with the situation said the ECB had written to financial institutions and told them to limit their reliance on back-to-back booking models by 2022. (FT)

EU Commission letter stated the targets in Italy budget are a source of "serious concern". (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte’s office reportedly said Italy wants constructive dialogue with the EU. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Salvini said they will not backtrack on their budget plans, despite market pressure. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister Altmaier said the government is willing to talk with the US about equal tariffs on cars. (Newswires)

Turkish Finance Minister says they are to announce a plan to counter inflation tomorrow. (Newswires)

BRAZILIAN ELECTION

Far-right candidate Bolsonaro won the first round of elections but failed to get an outright victory, as he managed to bag 46.1% of valid votes (short of the 50% needed for an outright victory) while left-wing Workers’ Party candidate Haddad came second with 29.2%. The runoff election is to take place on 28th October 2018 where opinion polls conducted before the election predicted that the candidates would be tied, according to the BBC

GEOPOLITICS

An official who is part of US Secretary of State Pompeo’s delegation said the US-North Korea deal is to be a “long haul”, while he added the trip has been better than the last one. North Korean Leader Kim Jung Un said he is satisfied with the talk with US Secretary of State Pompeo and has offered to stop ICBMs in return for war ending. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US and North Korea are close to an agreement on logistics for a second summit and added that the North Korean leader said he is ready to allow international inspectors to a nuclear site and a missile engine test site. (Newswires)

There were reports that North Korean leader Kim Jung Un is to visit Russia soon. Furthermore, Chinese President Xi is to visit North Korea. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Bullard (Non-voter, Dove) reiterated he does not see much inflationary pressure in the US economy, and added that wage growth is where it should be, while he said in his opinion, the Fed is close to the neutral level. Bullard also said there is plenty of prospects for trade talk going forward with China and he does not see recessions in the horizon right now. He also said that the US needs quicker productivity growth to maintain GDP growth rates. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Key European indices are down, with DAX Dec-18 futures testing 12,000 to the downside and the FTSE MIB significantly lagging its peers, down over 1.5%. This follows an EU commission letter stating that Italy’s budget targets are a source of serious concern in particular impacting Italian banks. Weakness in Italian banking stocks has pressured the financial sector, with this segment down by almost 1%

Major sectors are all down, with energy down by over 1% following comments that the White House may alleviate some Iranian sanctions, and IT names lagging their peers in continuation of price action seen in the US on Friday

In terms of individual equities Norsk Hydro are leading equities being up 4.6% following reports that aluminium refining is to restart at half capacity. Additionally, Schroders are up over 1% following speculation around a GBP 13bln joint venture with Lloyds. Deutsche Bank is down over 1.5% amidst reports that MIFID II is affecting revenues.

FX

DXY - The index and broad Usd have rebounded further from last Friday’s post-NFP lows, albeit not uniformly as the safer-havens are bucking the trend, but enough to nudge the DXY back up towards 96.000. Market holidays in Japan and the US ahead (latter only partial) may have exacerbated price action/moves, but it’s certainly been a risk-off return from Golden Week in China and the Italian budget issue continues weigh on investor sentiment. Back to the Dollar, or rather the index, and beyond the big figure last week’s peak was 96.124.

CAD - The biggest G10 loser as oil prices retreat to compound the overall downturn in risk sentiment, and the Loonie retreats to 1.3000 vs its US counterpart, eyeing a couple of tech levels just above (1.3013 and 1.3018) having failed to derive any lasting support from Canadian jobs data.

EUR/GBP - The next major underperformers, and both losing grip of round numbers/psychological handles in relatively quick order amidst stops and the aforementioned bearish factors. The single currency is under 1.1500 and Cable sub-1.3100, but the former is holding above decent option expiry interest at 1.1450 (1.5 bn) and the latter has regained some poise having tested 1.3050 stops, with Brexit impulses still supportive on balance.

JPY - A clean break of stops at 113.50, and chart supports at 113.56/113.42 (Tenkan and Fib respectively) has propelled the Jpy up to almost 113.25 vs the Greenback as the more attractive currency of the pairing during periods of pronounced risk aversion.

NZD/AUD/CHF - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, as the Kiwi and Aud pair some losses off fresh lows circa 0.6425 and 0.7040 respectively, while the Franc remains capped ahead of 0.9900, albeit bouncing firmly through 1.1400 against the Eur. 

EM - A bit of a mixed bag in terms of performance across the region, with the Rand hit hard after rumours/reports that SA Finance Minister may quit, but the Lira holding up better vs a strong Dollar ahead of the Government’s inflation combating measures due to be announced on Tuesday. Similarly, the Peso is benefiting from pre-positioning before the Real re-opens after Sunday’s Brazilian election and a bigger than anticipated 1st round victory by Bolsonaro. However, the Rouble has been undermined by a retreat in Brent and unable to reap the reward of speculation that US sanctions may be less harsh after mid-term elections. Usd/Zar around 14.8500, Usd/Try near 6.1600, Usd/Mxn close to 18.8300 and Usd/Rub hovering just under 67.0000.

COMMODITIES

The crude complex is in negative territory with Brent breaking the USD 83.00/BBL level to the downside amid suggestions from the US Government that exemptions may be granted to countries who have made efforts to cut Iranian oil imports. This also comes amid the possibility of a Saudi-Kuwaiti oil field restart and further confirmation by Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih that 1.3mln BPD of spare capacity can be used “if needed”. This has increased the possibility of rising supply to the oil market, and pushed both Brent and WTI down by over 1%.

In metals markets, gold has broken through the USD 1200/OZ level to the downside as the yellow metal is being hit by a stronger dollar. Aluminium prices are also in the red, with prices falling by over 4%, after a Brazilian court ruled that Norsk hydro’s aluminium plant may be reopened, albeit at a lower production level. Zinc and copper have also slipped due to the effects from a stronger USD.

FIXED INCOME

Some calm after a bout or several waves of fast market buying and selling in debt markets pushed Bunds clearly through the next set of upside chart targets and well beyond the 158.00 marker to a fresh Eurex peak of 158.23 (+62 ticks on the day), while the slide in BTPs once 120.00 finally gave way was even more dramatic, climaxing (for now at least) with the loss of 119.00 (118.94 low, -217 ticks). Elsewhere, shallower and tamer moves in Gilts and US Treasuries, but in line with German bonds as the former advanced to 120.04 (+32 ticks) on Liffe and the latter rebounded to new overnight session highs. Tech-wise, nothing much between here and 117-31 in 10 year USTs, 158.48 for Bunds and 120.10 for Gilts, while BTPs are looking below 118.00 if the latest attempt to recover fails.

subject: A Senior Sun Political Editor has said that Brexit Minister Raab has not confirmed his visit to Brussels this week
RANsquawk EU Mid Session - BTP 10 year yields hit 4 year highs as Italian turmoil continues; China cuts RRR but fails to prop up sentiment - 8th October 2018

Usd/Zar around 14.8500, Usd/Try near 6.1600, Usd/Mxn close to 18.8300 and Usd/Rub hovering just under 67.0000.

FIXED INCOME

Some calm after a bout or several waves of fast market buying and selling in debt markets pushed Bunds clearly through the next set of upside chart targets and well beyond the 158.00 marker to a fresh Eurex peak of 158.23 (+62 ticks on the day), while the slide in BTPs once 120.00 finally gave way was even more dramatic, climaxing (for now at least) with the loss of 119.00 (118.94 low, -217 ticks). Elsewhere, shallower and tamer moves in Gilts and US Treasuries, but in line with German bonds as the former advanced to 120.04 (+32 ticks) on Liffe and the latter rebounded to new overnight session highs. Tech-wise, nothing much between here and 117-31 in 10 year USTs, 158.48 for Bunds and 120.10 for Gilts, while BTPs are looking below 118.00 if the latest attempt to recover fails.

COMMODITIES

The crude complex is in negative territory with Brent breaking the USD 83.00/BBL level to the downside amid suggestions from the US Government that exemptions may be granted to countries who have made efforts to cut Iranian oil imports. This also comes amid the possibility of a Saudi-Kuwaiti oil field restart and further confirmation by Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih that 1.3mln BPD of spare capacity can be used “if needed”. This has increased the possibility of rising supply to the oil market, and pushed both Brent and WTI down by over 1%.

In metals markets, gold has broken through the USD 1200/OZ level to the downside as the yellow metal is being hit by a stronger dollar. Aluminium prices are also in the red, with prices falling by over 4%, after a Brazilian court ruled that Norsk hydro’s aluminium plant may be reopened, albeit at a lower production level. Zinc and copper have also slipped due to the effects from a stronger USD.

FX Morning Colour: risk-averse flows/positioning gathering momentum
content:
DXY

The index and broad Usd have rebounded further from last Friday’s post-NFP lows, albeit not uniformly as the safer-havens are bucking the trend, but enough to nudge the DXY back up towards 96.000. Market holidays in Japan and the US ahead (latter only partial) may have exacerbated price action/moves, but it’s certainly been a risk-off return from Golden Week in China and the Italian budget issue continues weigh on investor sentiment. Back to the Dollar, or rather the index, and beyond the big figure last week’s peak was 96.124.

CAD

The biggest G10 loser as oil prices retreat to compound the overall downturn in risk sentiment, and the Loonie retreats to 1.3000 vs its US counterpart, eyeing a couple of tech levels just above (1.3013 and 1.3018) having failed to derive any lasting support from Canadian jobs data.

EUR/GBP

The next major underperformers, and both losing grip of round numbers/psychological handles in relatively quick order amidst stops and the aforementioned bearish factors. The single currency is under 1.1500 and Cable sub-1.3100, but the former is holding above decent option expiry interest at 1.1450 (1.5 bn) and the latter has regained some poise having tested 1.3050 stops, with Brexit impulses still supportive on balance.

JPY

A clean break of stops at 113.50, and chart supports at 113.56/113.42 (Tenkan and Fib respectively) has propelled the Jpy up to almost 113.25 vs the Greenback as the more attractive currency of the pairing during periods of pronounced risk aversion.

NZD/AUD/CHF

All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, as the Kiwi and Aud pair some losses off fresh lows circa 0.6425 and 0.7040 respectively, while the Franc remains capped ahead of 0.9900, albeit bouncing firmly through 1.1400 against the Eur.  

EM

A bit of a mixed bag in terms of performance across the region, with the Rand hit hard after rumours/reports that SA Finance Minister may quit, but the Lira holding up better vs a strong Dollar ahead of the Government’s inflation combating measures due to be announced on Tuesday. Similarly, the Peso is benefiting from pre-positioning before the Real re-opens after Sunday’s Brazilian election and a bigger than anticipated 1st round victory by Bolsonaro. However, the Rouble has been undermined by a retreat in Brent and unable to reap the reward of speculation that US sanctions may be less harsh after mid-term elections. Usd/Zar around 14.8500, Usd/Try near 6.1600, Usd/Mxn close to 18.8300 and Usd/Rub hovering just under 67.0000.

subject: Fixed Income: core bonds extend gains as Italian bonds succumb to more downside
content: The 120.00 mark in 10 year Italian BTPs is providing some support, but has been breached to give Bunds and Gilts a bit more upside momentum amidst broader risk aversion on the return of Chinese markets from Golden Week. To recap, the US-China trade rift rumbles on and even though the PBoC cut its RRR again, stocks have been hit hard and the Yuan is weakening towards prior intervention levels, on top of the budget angst between Rome and Brussels. Hence, core or safe haven debt are benefiting from a grinding bid to test resistance levels in Bunds and Gilts ahead of 158.00 and 120.00 respectively, and a similar pattern is evolving in FX where the broad Usd, Jpy and Chf are outperforming vs the likes of the Gbp, Eur and commodity bloc/high beta currencies.

subject: MS trade of the week: buy Gbp/Aud at market (circa 1.8540), targeting 1.9500 and stop at 1.7900
Gilts and Short Sterling futures somewhat betwixt and between
content: UK debt and the STIR strip have returned to Liffe on the back foot, mostly and marginally, amidst rather mixed impulses via broadly upbeat Brexit deal vibes vs firmer core Eurozone bonds on the back of renewed pressure in Italian assets. The 10 year benchmark is holding in a 119.63-74 range vs last Friday’s 119.72 settlement, while 3 month futures are now flat to 1 tick adrift compared to 3 ticks below par at worst. Note, an empty domestic docket today, but a busier agenda this week including the relatively new monthly GDP update from the ONS alongside ip.

subject: ECB says banks borrowed 70mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 641.4bln with it overnight
Bunds: bucking bearish US leads as BTPs buckle again
content: The 10 year German debt future is grinding higher after a modest markdown off Monday’s Eurex open and very early dip to 157.50 vs last week’s 157.61 close, and the dip buying is all or almost entirely down to the latest slump in Italian debt amidst ongoing concern about the country’s medium term budget. Indeed, the benchmark BTP has tumbled to fresh contract lows at 120.25 (-86 ticks), with the corresponding yield rallying above 3.50% and spread to Bunds approaching 300 bp again, as the latter eases back under 0.55% and the future rebounds to 157.72. Ahead, Eurozone sentiment via Sentix and a speech from ECB’s Nowotny due before the weekly QE update and first at the new, lower monthly pace.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

8th October 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded on the backfoot as the region mimicked the lead from Wall St. where the S&P 500 posted its worst week in nearly a month as the tech sector underperformed, while Nasdaq Comp. pulled back over a percent as tech giants lagged and the Dow notched its second straight weekly declines as the index was pressured by heavyweights Intel and Caterpillar. ASX 200 (-1.1%) was weighed on by material and financial names following ANZ’s profit warning which dragged the likes of CBA, WBC and NAB lower in sympathy, while KOSPI (-0.4%) initially outperformed amid positive developments in the Korean peninsula before dipping in the red and Nikkei 225 is closed due to a public holiday in Japan.  Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-3.0%) plummeted as mainland China played catch-up, with participants re-entering the market and reacting to last week’s trade developments, rising yields, China downgrades and weak Caixin manufacturing data. Hang Seng (-0.8%) eroded initial gains as sentiment turned sour along with the mainland.

FTSE

Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS LN) – The co. is reportedly considering getting rid of its corporate name due to reputational damage from the financial crisis alongside RBS’s much-disliked restructuring. (Times)

Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY LN) / Schroders (SDR LN) – Lloyds is considering a deal for Schroders GBP 13bln wealth management division, with the branch set to be a joint venture owned by both companies. (Times)

BT (BT/A LN) – The co. in reportedly in talks with Apple (AAPL) over using EE as a major distributor of Apple TV set-top boxes. (Telegraph)

Prudential (PRU LN) – the co.’s Asia chief said they are looking at acquisitions in Asia to boost growth. (Newswires)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – The Australian competition regulator has said that the co.’s partner Port of Newcastle Operations has to reduce their charges for ships entering the port. (Newswires)

Standard Life Aberdeen (SLA LN) – Co. have made an approach for ex-HSBC Chairman Flint to replace Chairman Grimstone, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK Housing Names – The Treasury is reportedly considering introducing a “good landlord” tax benefit for landlords who sell homes to the next generation of buyers. The plan is to be called “Help to Buy” and would avoid capital gains tax when selling to tenants who have lived in the property for over 3 years. (Guardian)

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The Mifid II rules are hitting the co.’s wealth management 2018 revenue and profit, as according to Boersen-Zeitung cited sources. (Boersen-Zeitung)

Daimler (DAI GY) – the co. has said it will begin to build a batter plant as part of its USD 1bln  investment to upgrade its factory in Alabama. (Newswires)

CAC

Air France (AF FP) – The co. reported a load factor +0.2ppts to 88.6% vs. last year, and passengers carried +2.7% from Prev. (Newswires)

Suez Environment (SEV FP) – Board of Engie (ENGI FP) requires more time to make decision on their stake in the Co. (Newswires)

ADP (ADP FP) – French government could choose investors in the Co. next summer, according to reports. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

KERING (KER FP) REITERATED OVERWIEGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

ILIAD (ILD FP) UPGRADED TONEUTRAL FROM UNDERPERFORM AT MACQUARIE

AXA (CS FP) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM MARKET PERFORM AT KEEFE BRUYETTE

PAN EUROPE

Mediaset (MS IM) / EI Towers (EIT IM) – Italian masts group EI Towers were successfully taken over by broadcaster Mediaset and infrastructure fund F2i, investors tendered shares equivalent to 97.45% of capital. Mediaset to get a capital gain over EUR 510mln from the deals. (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM) / Vivendi (VIV FP) – Mediaset have been contacted by Vivendi’s lawyers seeking a compromise regarding the companies’ legal dispute according to La Repubblica. Following this, a Mediaset spokesman stated that there had been no contact between the two companies in recent months. (La Repubblica)

ENI (ENI IM) – According to the chief executive of Sonatrach, Algeria’s state owned oil and gas company, they will launch offshore drilling with France’s Total and Italy’s ENI in the start of 2019 on two sites east and west of Algeria. (Newswires)

Luxottica (LUX IM) – Italian antitrust authority stated it had launched a probe into Luxottica’s acquisition of Barberini; a sun lens maker. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – CEO states that Co. remain committed to asset sales and are exploring potential targets in Brazil. (Newswires)

US

* SPX -0.6% at 2886, NDX -1.2% at 7399, DJI -0.7% at 26449. SECTORS: Energy -0.1%, Materials -0.8%, Industrials -0.5%, Cons Discretionary -0.8%, Cons Staples -0.2%, Healthcare -0.1%, Financials -0.5%, Tech -1.3%, Telecoms -1.0%, Utilities +1.5%.

content:

If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks traded on the backfoot as the region mimicked the lead from Wall St. where the S&P 500 posted its worst week in nearly a month
  • The Telegraph reports The EU is preparing to offer Theresa May a “supercharged” free trade deal this week but will reject Mrs May’s demands for frictionless tradee
  • The Telegraph also reports that Brexiteers offered UK PM May a lifeline that will see EU officials based at UK borders
  • Brazilian far-right candidate Bolsonaro won the first round of elections but failed to get an outright victory, as he managed to bag 46.1% of valid votes
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German industrial production, Fed’s Bullard and ECB’s Nowotny, US Columbus Day (US equities open)

 

ASIA

Asian stocks traded on the backfoot as the region mimicked the lead from Wall St. where the S&P 500 posted its worst week in nearly a month as the tech sector underperformed, while Nasdaq Comp. pulled back over a percent as tech giants lagged and the Dow notched its second straight weekly declines as the index was pressured by heavyweights Intel and Caterpillar. ASX 200 (-1.1%) was weighed on by material and financial names following ANZ’s profit warning which dragged the likes of CBA, WBC and NAB lower in sympathy, while KOSPI (-0.4%) initially outperformed amid positive developments in the Korean peninsula before dipping in the red and Nikkei 225 is closed due to a public holiday in Japan.  Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-3.0%) plummeted as mainland China played catch-up, with participants re-entering the market and reacting to last week’s trade developments, rising yields, China downgrades and weak Caixin manufacturing data. Hang Seng (-0.8%) eroded initial gains as sentiment turned sour along with the mainland.

PBoC cut the RRR for some banks by 100bps to 14.50% from 15.50% (effective Oct 15th) in order to release CNY 750bln of liquidity. This is the fourth cut this year, while the central bank said it will continue to adopt prudent, neutral monetary policy and added the cut will not lead to pressure of CNY depreciation. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8957 (Prev. 6.8792) (weakest since May 11th 2017)
PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 100bln.

US Commerce Secretary Ross said he does not expect movement on China talks until after midterms, he added the USMCA 'non-market country' clause to act as a poison pill against potential trade deals with China, and the US could be replicated in future trade deals with EU and Japan. (Newswires)

US Department of Homeland Security said they have no reason to question denials by US tech firms that Chinese spies infiltrated US computer networks via microchips. (Newswires)

Chinese Caixin Services PMI Sep 53.1 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.5) (Newswires)
China Caixin Composite PMI (Sep) 52.1 (Prev. 52.0)

UK

Head of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker told Austrian press that the chance of the UK and the EU agreeing a Brexit deal has grown in the last few days. He added that while he was not sure an agreement could be reached by October, it could be by November. Juncker declined to comment on whether he believed that Brexit might yet be avoided, given the divisions in the British government and parliament on the issue. (BBC/ The Guardian)

The EU is preparing to offer Theresa May a “supercharged” free trade deal this week but will reject Mrs May’s demands for frictionless trade, it has emerged. The offer from Brussels, which will be put to British negotiators on Wednesday, is said to contain “30 to 40 per cent” of the demands made in Mrs May’s Chequers proposal. (The Telegraph/Times) The Telegraph also reports that UK PM May will soon have to tell the UK that the country will be forced to stay in the Customs Union. (The Telegraph)

The Telegraph reported that Brexiteers offered UK PM May a lifeline that will see EU officials based at UK borders in a package of concessions to help unlock a Canada-style trade deal with Brussels. (The Telegraph) Reports in the Independent took a slightly different spin on the situation by stating that Conservative Brexiteers are giving UK PM May an ultimatum, that if her negotiating strategy fails she must accept plans for a Canada-style trade deal or face a leadership challenge. (The Independent) Further to this, the Times reports that Brexiteers have issued a last-ditch threat to vote down the budget and destroy the government unless UK PM May takes a tougher line with Brussels. The Times also reported that Brexiteers warned UK PM May that she could keep the UK within the EU customs arrangements only until 2022. (The Times)

UK PM May has appealed to Labour voters unhappy with Labour leader Corbyn's leadership to consider switching to the Conservatives. Writing in the Observer the PM insisted her party had a "moderate and patriotic programme". (BBC) May has also drawn up plans for a secret charm offensive aimed at persuading dozens of Labour MPs to back her Brexit deal even if it costs Labour leader Corbyn the chance to be PM, the Guardian has learned. Senior Tories say they have been in private contact with a number of Labour MPs over several months. (The Guardian) The Telegraph reported that UK Government whips in talks with 25 Labour MPs to push Chequers deal through Parliament. (The Telegraph)

SNP leader Sturgeon has said her MPs would back a new Brexit referendum if there is a vote to approve one in parliament. (The Independent)

Japanese PM Abe said he would welcome the UK to a TPP trade deal with "open arms". (FT)

The ECB warns banks to curtail booking trades and loans in UK post-Brexit; three people familiar with the situation said the ECB had written to financial institutions and told them to limit their reliance on back-to-back booking models by 2022. (FT)

EU

EU Commission letter stated the targets in Italy budget are a source of "serious concern". (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte’s office reportedly said Italy wants constructive dialogue with the EU. (Newswires)

German Economy Minister Altmaier said the government is willing to talk with the US about equal tariffs on cars. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed France at AA/A-1+, outlook stable. (Newswires)              

BRAZILIAN ELECTION

Far-right candidate Bolsonaro won the first round of elections but failed to get an outright victory, as he managed to bag 46.1% of valid votes (short of the 50% needed for an outright victory) while left-wing Workers’ Party candidate Haddad came second with 29.2%. The runoff election is to take place on 28th October 2018 where opinion polls conducted before the election predicted that the candidates would be tied, according to the BBC.

FX

FX markets were choppy with the dollar marginally firmer after initially fluctuating between gains and losses. EUR/USD and GBP/USD trade flat, above the 1.1500 and 1.3100 levels respectively, while MXN acted as a proxy to the BRL during the Brazilian Election exit polls where “market friendly” Bolsorano won the first round but failed to get an outright win, hence there will be a runoff election between himself and Haddad on October 28th.  Elsewhere, JPY continues to weaken with the currency eyeing 114.00 to the upside against the greenback.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were lower across the board with WTI and Brent below USD 74.00/bbl and USD 83.50/bbl respectively as oil markets unwind some risk premium following reports last week that the White House was mulling whether to waive some sanctions on countries’ imports of Iranian oil. Elsewhere, gold dipped below USD 1200/oz as the USD gained some traction, while copper was also in the red amid a strengthening greenback and soured risk sentiment.

Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Salman said he sees a deal with Kuwait to restart oil fields soon and added the nation has 1.3mln bbl/day of spare capacity ready to be used if market needs it. He said Saudi Arabia is now pumping about 10.7mln bpd and can add a further 1.3mln "if the market needs that". He also noted that higher price seen in the last month is not due to Iran but mostly because of things happening in Canada, Mexico, Libya, Venezuela and other countries. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak discussed ways to enhance crude oil extraction in Libya with NOC's Sanallah; according to a NOC statement. (Newswires)

NHC said Tropical Storm Michael is stronger, heavy rains expected over Western Cuba tonight and Monday, threat to the North-eastern US Gulf Coast is increasing. Note: Michael is located in the Atlantic. (Newswires)

Baker Hughes rig count (5 Oct): Oil rigs -2 at 861, gas rigs unchanged at 189, total rigs -2 at 1052. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

An official who is part of US Secretary of State Pompeo’s delegation said the US-North Korea deal is to be a “long haul”, while he added the trip has been better than the last one. North Korean Leader Kim Jung Un said he is satisfied with the talk with US Secretary of State Pompeo and has offered to stop ICBMs in return for war ending. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US and North Korea are close to an agreement on logistics for a second summit and added that the North Korean leader said he is ready to allow international inspectors to a nuclear site and a missile engine test site. (Newswires)

There were reports that North Korean leader Kim Jung Un is to visit Russia soon. Furthermore, Chinese President Xi is to visit North Korea. (Newswires)

US

It was another day of higher yields across the Treasury curve, which bear-steepened once again, though yields were off their highs by settlement. Selling was seen following a decent labour market report which showed wages ticking up in September. Many parts of the curves hit fresh multi-year highs. FOMC voter John Williams said the yield curve flattening did not portend a recession, and sees inflation rising further, which helped yields crawl higher. Major curve spreads were wider at settlement by between 1-3bps. NOTE: US fixed income markets will be closed on Monday for Columbus Day. * US T-note futures (Z8) settles 9 ticks lower at 117-21+.

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said incoming data has been stronger this year than he anticipated; and added he might have underestimated momentum of aggregate demand, if so that would require higher paths of rates. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-voter, Dove) reiterated he does not see much inflationary pressure in the US economy, and added that wage growth is where it should be, while he said in his opinion, the Fed is close to the neutral level. Bullard also said there is plenty of prospects for trade talk going forward with China and he does not see recessions in the horizon right now. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-voter, Neutral) said he would be comfortable with a December hike and he can see three additional rate hikes by June 2019. (Newswires)

Nominee for the Supreme Court Kavanaugh has been sworn in, the Senate backed his nomination by 50 votes to 48. (BBC)

content:
Asian stocks trade on the backfoot following a similar lead from Wall St. where the S&P 500 posted its worst week in nearly a month as the tech sector underperformed, while Nasdaq Comp. pulled back over a percent as tech giants lagged and the Dow notched its second straight weekly declines as the index was pressured by heavyweights Intel and Caterpillar. ASX 200 (-1.0%) is weighed on by financial names following ANZ’s profit warning which dragged the likes of CBA, WBC and NAB lower in sympathy, while KOSPI (+0.2%) erased initial losses following positive developments in the Korean peninsula and Nikkei 225 is closed due to a public holiday.  Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch) is flat after having opened in the green as the index takes the breather from last week’s losses and Shanghai Comp. (-2.00%) underperforms as mainland China plays catch-up as participants re-enter the market after a week-long holiday.

FX markets are choppy with the dollar fluctuating between gains and losses, albeit trading in a tight range. EUR/USD and GBP/USD trade flat, above the 1.1500 and 1.3100 levels respectively, while MXN acted as a proxy to the BRL during the Brazilian Election exit polls where “market friendly” Bolsorano won the first round but failed to get an outright win, hence there will be a runoff election between himself and Haddad on October 28th.  Elsewhere, JPY continues to weaken with the currency eyeing 114.00 to the upside against the greenback.

Tech names - US Department of Homeland Security says they have no reason to question denials by US tech firms that Chinese spies infiltrated US computer networks via microchips. (Newswires)

Sunac China (1918 HK) – reports Sep contracted sales +24% Y/Y at CNY 53.4bln. (Newswires)

Evergrande Health (0708 HK) - Faraday futures seek to scrap the sale of stake. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

- PBoC cut the RRR for some banks by 100bps to 14.50% from 15.50% in order to release another CNY 750bln. This is the fourth cut this year, while the central bank said it will continue to adopt prudent, neutral monetary policy and added the cut will not lead to pressure of CNY depreciation. (Newswires)

- US Commerce Secretary Ross said he does not expect movement on China talks until after midterms, he added the USMCA clause to act as a poison pill against potential trade deals with China, and the US could be replicated in future trade deals with EU and Japan. (Newswires)

- White House Advisor Kudlow said US President Trump thinks the relationship with China is broken; and there may be a meeting between Trump and Chinese President Xi in November. (Newswires)
